dublin_core.dcvalue: Using 2 field procedures the authors assessed impacts of cell phone use on mild forms of driver aggression Participants were 135 drivers traveling within a city of approximately 17 000 people in an otherwise little populated region of western North Dakota The authors videotaped the participants while a confederate driver in a low status vehicle frustrated them In Experiment 1 the confederate was traveling well under the posted speed limit In Experiment 2 the confederate remained motionless at a stoplight that had turned green When the confederate visibly talked on a hand held cell phone n 67 male drivers exhibited their frustration by honking their horn more quickly and frequently than did drivers in no cell phone trials and female drivers were more angry according to blind judgments of videotaped facial expressions that were compared with those of drivers in no cell phone trials n 68 The present results suggested that driver cell phone use contributes to the growing crisis of roadway aggression
